Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Observers: AD & CD. Plotted: AD Open slope near ridge top above Casio start zone.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
The top layer of mid-February snow was about 10cm thick and we got a score of PST 15/100 SF @94cm with the slab fracture occurring at the same location as the saw, 15cm. We loaded another 20-30cm of snow on top of undisturbed snowpack and let it sinter for 2 hours. We isolated a new PST column. When we performed the new loaded-slab simulation PST, we got the same result PST 15/100 SF. But this time the slab fracture went about 15 cm further back. We kept running the saw up the remaining PST column, and the slab propagated a fracture to the end, PST 10/70 End. Not standardized, but information nonetheless. This suggested that a thicker or more cohesive slab may have the means to propagate a failure through the NSF layer.
On Feb 22-24, the area accumulated ~50cm of new snow, along with wind loading.
On Feb. 26th, groups reported widespread cracking and collapsing in this area. See image. Several groups backed off avalanche prone slopes, due to cracks, collapsing, and ECTP results. No naturals or skier triggered avalanches reported.
A nearby pit had a thin crust between the mid-February snow and NSF layer.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: other; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug near the debris of a recent avalanche.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We did a loaded PST and a loaded CT. The load was 10cm of snow that we added to the surface and let it sit for 180 minutes. It was 1f in hardness by the time we did the tests. The tests failed at the base of our artificial slab on the current snow surface. In the loaded PST, we targeted the facet layer @ 179.5-175cm. The fracture started to propagate in that layer at a 22cm cut length then quickly stepped up to the interface between the current snow surface and the artificial slab. Results: Loaded (+10cm 1f slab added) PST 22/100 END started @ 176cm then the fracture stepped up to 185 cm. Loaded (+10cm 1f slab added) CT 1 SC @ 185cm.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Stephens Glacier. Lower Shoulder of the Treatment Center. Lots of sluffing and very soft slab release during prior storm. A pocket may have released when skiing over a sharp convexity but the light was so flat that we couldn't see for sure. Generally favorable structure, but the bottom facets would be a concern in areas where it is thinner and has a thinner/weaker slab above it. This pit was ~ 150 meters off of the LZ in an area where the snowpack was likely stronger than mid slope.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Gott veður og sólskin, heiður himinn. Grófum niður á 50cm en þar var 10-20cm mjög þykkt lag sem ekki var grafið í gegnum. Heildardýptin var 160cm. Nýfallinn snjór ofan á hjarnið en þétt lag á 27-30cm. Á þessum skilum brotnaði við stöðuleikapróf. Rekupróf gaf litlar vísbendingar. Efsta lagið var mjög laus snjór og nokkur hætta á að setja flekaflóð af stað af mannavöldum. Mögulega hafði sólskin áhrif á hitastig við yfirborð, en þar má sjá töluverðan hitastigul.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Cracking; Ski tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Warming beginning mid afternoon on S facing slopes. Loose dry point release observed in 35+ degree W facing gully. Shooting cracks from ski tips within new snow when touring up S facing terrain to top of Carbon Hill. Ski tracks down steep N facing line near Chattanooga corner, taunting the "persistent slab" problem. Significant snow transport from N to S on alpine ridges throughout the day and into the evening. Layer of concern observed on NW slope at 11700' seemed to be buried surface facets under new storm snow.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking;
Pit is adjacent to avalanche; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Sjá má bletti víðsvegar um dalinn með bláum ís. Snjóþekjan er á köflum þunn á háum melum og börðum. Á ferð um dalinn fóru af stað tvö flóð með fjarbroti í um 300-500 metra fjarlægð. Ekki sáust nýleg flóð utan þessa sem fóru af stað þegar ekið var um dalinn. Tekin skyndigryfja í eins vísandi hlíð örlítið sunnar en flóðin. Stöðugleikapróf gáfu niðurstöðu við miðlungsáraun, en þegar stigið var inn á snjóþekjuna fyrir ofan gryfjustæðið rann snjóþekjan af stað við litla áraun á glæra hjarni. Hitamælir varð straumlaus

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Relatively stable snowpack conditions are observed on moderately steep slopes with a N/NE aspect.
The entire mountain is severely windblown and the surface snow is hard, uneven, crusty, and icy in spots. The location where the snowpit was dug was one of the very few spots on the entire slope with some windblown powder on top.
The layer of potential concern starts at around 35 cm deep (at this location at least - will likely be shallower in most other places). There is some sugary snow present in it and the layer below as well. However, despite this, its surface is not too slippery, with 2 consequtive compression test performed, and on average there is some breakup of the layer above it around CT27 and a smooth, Q2 slide on its surface at the very end on CT30.
The layer below this one also contains some sugary snow crystals in spots.
No spontaneous avalanche activity is anywhere in the region. Given the forecast the trend will likely continue over the next week on similar slopes.
JC DM. Sparse TL burnt glade, Wind loaded.
Priority was training. Quick Ob as we waited for folks.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Patrollers involved: N. Grimes, N. Fuller. Snowpit dug in an unskied area of Casper Bowl. Pit documents the widespread Near Surface Facets that exist in the Tetons. This layer has the potential to create significant instability once a load is added.
found depth hoar in layer 30cm - 10 cm. Lots of mixed crystals

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug pit in fairly wind sheltered spot in open woodland. Surprised by lack of facets in most of the snowpack. "Ice Sandwich" definite concern here. Wind switched from N to S around this time. On decent, storm slab (top 13cm) would release on rollovers. Localized whumping.
sondeados 110 cm.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Laurin linjasta itään. Kruunun leveys 45-50 metriä. Vyöryn pituus 250-300 metriä. Kertymäalueella lunta km. 160-180 cm. Laukaisun syy tuntematon. Murtuma yläpäässä iso kivi jyrkänteellä. Murtuma jatkui koko ajan alaspäin kaartaen.
Hitaprófill var ekki gerður, en athugað var hvort að hitastigull væri yfir þunna íslaginu

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: OBS!: Endast struktur, inget test. HS 280+, Sten och mossa i mark i området. Mycket vindpåverkat område som helhet. Lätt marknära drev vid sporadiska tillfällen- knallhårt överlag.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: At the foot of the North Face of Todorka - the Venue of Bansko Freeride world Qualifier 2022. On this day activity of new soft slab on top of soft snow, on western locations deeper; The next days stabilizing, no further avalanche activity (till 15.02.2022, when the profile was published)
Small lee slope at upper TL. DM, BK, GK

Pit_Observation.activities: We snowmobiled slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Bedöm drevsnöflak. Identifiera potentiella PWL. Terräng: profil platsen motsvarar få ställen på Anåfjället. Mycket terräng är avblåst och det som är laddat är mycket hård på ytan. Brant och gles skog som är det ända ställe som är korsladdad.

Mid way up Big Blue, east aspect, 6155 ft. Surface - SH (3mm) and DF. Jan 12 Rain seems to be overall still bridging but broke roughly through rain layer on and after ECTN 18 @36 cm . No time for 2nd ECT or PST.
TL. Öppet området i björkskogen.
SONDEADOS 120 CM DE 265CM.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Adjacent pit on south aspect produced ECTN13 30cm down on MF/facet combo and CT3 Q2 @ 7cm down
Loose Dry avalanches were easy to trigger on steep northerly terrain below treeline. These 20-30cm deep facet sluffs are running relatively fast and long distances on hard bed surfaces, and could easily knock someone off their feet.
Stenig terräng. Tunt snötäcke. Vindpåverkat område. Skarlagret (ej bara vindskare) på ytan stämmer inte riktigt med Jan blidan- som vi bara sett upp till 1000m hittills.
